io.atomix.variables

Class AbstractDistributedValue<T extends AbstractDistributedValue<T,U>,U>

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.atomix.resource.AbstractResource<T>
      • io.atomix.variables.AbstractDistributedValue<T,U>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Managed<T>, Resource<T>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DistributedLong, DistributedValue

    public abstract class AbstractDistributedValue<T extends AbstractDistributedValue<T,U>,U>
extends AbstractResource<T>
    Base class for distributed atomic variables.

    This class provides functionality shared by DistributedValue and DistributedLong, including set, get, and atomic compare-and-set operations. The methods are closely modeled on those of Java's AtomicReference. Operations that modify the resource state are atomic. Operations that read resource state may be atomic depending on the configured read consistency level.

    Author:

      • Nested Class Summary

        • Nested classes/interfaces inherited from interface io.atomix.resource.Resource

          Resource.Config, Resource.Options, Resource.State

      • open

        public CompletableFuture<T> open()
        Description copied from interface: Resource
        Opens the resource.

        Once the resource is opened, the resource will be transitioned to the Resource.State.CONNECTED state and the returned CompletableFuture will be completed.

        Specified by:
        open in interface Managed<T extends AbstractDistributedValue<T,U>>
        Specified by:

        Overrides:

      • onChange

        public CompletableFuture<Listener<ValueChangeEvent<T>>> onChange(Consumer<ValueChangeEvent<T>> callback)
        Registers a listener to be called when the value changes.

      • get

        public CompletableFuture<U> get()
        Gets the current value.

        The value will be read using the configured read consistency level for the resource. For atomic reads, reads will be forwarded to the cluster leader. Weaker reads may be evaluated on non-leader nodes. However, consistency constraints guarantee that state will never go back in time.

        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed with the current value.

      • get

        public CompletableFuture<U> get(ReadConsistency consistency)
        Gets the current value.

        The value will be read using the provided read consistency level. For atomic reads, reads will be forwarded to the cluster leader. Weaker reads may be evaluated on non-leader nodes. However, consistency constraints guarantee that state will never go back in time.

        Parameters:
        consistency - The read consistency level.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed with the current value.

      • set

        public CompletableFuture<Void> set(U value)
        Sets the value.

        This is an atomic operation that is guaranteed to take place exactly once between the invocation of the method call and the completion of the returned CompletableFuture. Once the returned CompletableFuture is completed, all other instances of the resource can see the state change when writing or reading using atomic consistency.

        Parameters:
        value - The current value.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed once the value has been set.

      • set

        public CompletableFuture<Void> set(U value,
                                   Duration ttl)
        Sets the value with a time-to-live.

        This is an atomic operation that is guaranteed to take place exactly once between the invocation of the method call and the completion of the returned CompletableFuture. Once the returned CompletableFuture is completed, all other instances of the resource can see the state change when writing or reading using atomic consistency.

        The value set will be expired after the given Duration so long as it's not overridden by a later call from this or another instance of the resource. The time-to-live on the value is coarse grained, and the value is only guaranteed to expire up to a session timeout after the given time-to-live has expired.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to set.
        ttl - The time after which to expire the value.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed once the value has been set.

      • getAndSet

        public CompletableFuture<U> getAndSet(U value)
        Gets the current value and updates it.

        This is an atomic operation that is guaranteed to take place exactly once between the invocation of the method call and the completion of the returned CompletableFuture. Once the returned CompletableFuture is completed, all other instances of the resource can see the state change when writing or reading using atomic consistency.

        Once the operation is complete, the returned CompletableFuture will be completed with the value of the resource prior to setting the updated value.

        Parameters:
        value - The updated value.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed with the previous value.

      • getAndSet

        public CompletableFuture<U> getAndSet(U value,
                                      Duration ttl)
        Gets the current value and updates it, setting a time-to-live on the updated value.

        This is an atomic operation that is guaranteed to take place exactly once between the invocation of the method call and the completion of the returned CompletableFuture. Once the returned CompletableFuture is completed, all other instances of the resource can see the state change when writing or reading using atomic consistency.

        Once the operation is complete, the returned CompletableFuture will be completed with the value of the resource prior to setting the updated value. The value set will be expired after the given Duration so long as it's not overridden by a later call from this or another instance of the resource. The time-to-live on the value is coarse grained, and the value is only guaranteed to expire up to a session timeout after the given time-to-live has expired.

        Parameters:
        value - The updated value.
        ttl - The time after which to expire the value.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed with the previous value.

      • compareAndSet

        public CompletableFuture<Boolean> compareAndSet(U expect,
                                                U update)
        Compares the current value and updated it if expected value equals the current value.

        This is an atomic operation that is guaranteed to take place exactly once between the invocation of the method call and the completion of the returned CompletableFuture. If the expect value is equal to the current resource value, the value will be updated and the returned CompletableFuture will be completed true, otherwise the value will not be updated and the returned CompletableFuture will be completed false. In contrast to Java's atomic variables, value comparisons are done with Object.equals(Object) rather than ==. This is necessary because of serialization. Once the returned future is completed, all other instances of the resource can see the state change when writing or reading using atomic consistency.

        Parameters:
        expect - The expected value.
        update - The updated value.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed with a boolean value indicating whether the value was updated.

      • compareAndSet

        public CompletableFuture<Boolean> compareAndSet(U expect,
                                                U update,
                                                Duration ttl)
        Compares the current value and updated it if expected value equals the current value, setting a time-to-live on the updated value.

        This is an atomic operation that is guaranteed to take place exactly once between the invocation of the method call and the completion of the returned CompletableFuture. If the expect value is equal to the current resource value, the value will be updated and the returned CompletableFuture will be completed true, otherwise the value will not be updated and the returned CompletableFuture will be completed false. If the value is not updated then the provided time-to-live will not apply to the existing value. In contrast to Java's atomic variables, value comparisons are done with Object.equals(Object) rather than ==. This is necessary because of serialization. Once the returned future is completed, all other instances of the resource can see the state change when writing or reading using atomic consistency.

        If the value is changed, the updated value will be expired after the given Duration so long as it's not overridden by a later call from this or another instance of the resource. The time-to-live on the value is coarse grained, and the value is only guaranteed to expire up to a session timeout after the given time-to-live has expired.

        Parameters:
        expect - The expected value.
        update - The updated value.
        ttl - The time after which to expire the value.
        Returns:
        A completable future to be completed with a boolean value indicating whether the value was updated.
